content: I vaguely remember this from when it originally happened. It saddens me and sickens me to see students' rights being trampled to this point. They claim that they needed to "protect the students from drugs," but this was IBUPROFEN. ADVIL! Good grief, what was she going to do with it? Take it for a headache? Menstrual cramps? Americans are supposed to have protection against unreasonable search and seizure. Yes, those laws are supposed to keep police from overstepping against citizens, but... who the hell do those school officials think they are? What right to they have to tell a student to remove her clothes? And what ticks me off just as much... is this asinine restriction against students keeping the most basic medications in their bags. Why should a school nurse have to keep a student's medication in the office? It belongs to the student, not to the nurse. I don't feel that the nurse should have the right, on behalf of the school, to hold the students' medications, prescription or otherwise. For that matter, Advil can be purchased over-the-counter. There are no laws against it, no restrictions on how much a person can own. I just don't see what right the school officials had to do this to this girl, and why there's even a discussion over whether or not this should be allowed.
